docs.abstract: Ruling that Andrew Miller must comply with a subpoena, an appeals court upholds the legitimacy of Robert Mueller’s appointment as special counsel.
docs.snippet: Ruling that Andrew Miller must comply with a subpoena, an appeals court upholds the legitimacy of Robert Mueller’s appointment as special counsel.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Tuesday upheld the appointment of Robert S. Mueller III, the special counsel investigating ties between the Trump campaign and Russia, and ruled that a former aide to Roger J. Stone Jr., the longtime Trump adviser who was indicted last month, must testify before a grand jury.

headline.main: Aide to Roger Stone Must Testify in Russia Case, Appeals Court Rules
headline.print_headline: Aide to Trump Adviser Is Ordered to Testify In Russia Investigation

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

docs.abstract: Making a rare admission of a mistake, the special counsel’s office filed a memo in federal court revising its account of the evidence it used in asserting that Paul Manafort breached his plea deal.
docs.snippet: Making a rare admission of a mistake, the special counsel’s office filed a memo in federal court revising its account of the evidence it used in asserting that Paul Manafort breached his plea deal.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The special counsel’s office, citing new information from a cooperating witness, appeared on Wednesday to correct one element of its earlier allegations that Paul Manafort, President Trump’s former campaign chairman, lied about his contacts with a Russian business associate whom they have linked to Russian intelligence.

headline.main: Mueller’s Team Acknowledges New Information in Allegations That Manafort Lied
headline.print_headline: Legal Memo To Correct Part of File On Manafort

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

docs.abstract: Democrats focused on whether the president deliberately hid repayments to Michael Cohen from his 2017 financial disclosure form.
docs.snippet: Democrats focused on whether the president deliberately hid repayments to Michael Cohen from his 2017 financial disclosure form.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Michael D. Cohen’s congressional testimony on Wednesday revived questions about whether President Trump broke the law by failing to disclose that he footed the bill for a hush payment to a pornographic film actress.

headline.main: Cohen Testimony Raises Questions About Trump’s Financial Disclosure
headline.print_headline: Testimony Raises Doubts  About Disclosure Forms

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: Citizens for Responsibility and Ethics in Washington

docs.abstract: The House passed a measure to extend from three days to 10 the time the F.B.I. has to conduct background checks for gun purchasers flagged by the instant check system.
docs.snippet: The House passed a measure to extend from three days to 10 the time the F.B.I. has to conduct background checks for gun purchasers flagged by the instant check system.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House voted Thursday to extend the time allotted for the F.B.I. to conduct background checks for gun purchasers flagged by the national instant check system, the second major gun control bill to clear the chamber this week after two decades of inaction.

headline.main: Pelosi Passes Second Gun Control Bill and Puts Down Democratic Rebellion
headline.print_headline: Pelosi Quells Rebellion to Pass Second Gun Control Bill

docs.abstract: After the revelation that President Trump had ordered that his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, be granted a top-secret clearance, two committees are now seeking documents and interviews with officials.
docs.snippet: After the revelation that President Trump had ordered that his son-in-law, Jared Kushner, be granted a top-secret clearance, two committees are now seeking documents and interviews with officials.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A powerful Democratic House committee chairman investigating possible abuses of the government’s security clearance process stepped up demands on Friday to see key documents and interview potential witnesses from the White House in light of a new report that President Trump personally intervened to grant his son-in-law a top-secret clearance despite legal and national security concerns.

headline.main: House Democrats Demand Information From White House About Security Clearances
headline.print_headline: In Inquiry, Democrats Threaten A Subpoena

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform

docs.abstract: The president said he planned to issue an executive order that would help guarantee free speech on college campuses by putting their federal aid at risk.
docs.snippet: The president said he planned to issue an executive order that would help guarantee free speech on college campuses by putting their federal aid at risk.
docs.lead_paragraph: OXON HILL, Md. — President Trump said on Saturday that he planned to issue an executive order that would help guarantee free speech at colleges and universities by putting their federal aid at risk if they do not protect the viewpoints of students of all political stripes.

headline.main: Trump Says He Will Sign Free Speech Order for College Campuses
headline.print_headline: Trump Vows to Issue Order On Free Speech at Colleges

docs.abstract: Even without progress this week to shut down North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, the Trump administration is shelving massive military exercises that Pyongyang views as provocative.
docs.snippet: Even without progress this week to shut down North Korea’s nuclear weapons program, the Trump administration is shelving massive military exercises that Pyongyang views as provocative.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States and South Korea will suspend two large-scale joint military exercises this spring, two American officials said Friday, as part of President Trump’s efforts to maintain the truce he has struck with Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea.

headline.main: Pentagon Again Suspends Large-Scale Military Exercises With South Korea
headline.print_headline: U.S. to Curtail Training Games In South Korea

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces

docs.abstract: The president overruled concerns from intelligence officials and the top White House lawyer about giving his son-in-law access to sensitive information.
docs.snippet: The president overruled concerns from intelligence officials and the top White House lawyer about giving his son-in-law access to sensitive information.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump ordered his chief of staff to grant his son-in-law and senior adviser, Jared Kushner, a top-secret security clearance last year, overruling concerns flagged by intelligence officials and the White House’s top lawyer, four people briefed on the matter said.

headline.main: Trump Ordered Officials to Give Jared Kushner a Security Clearance
headline.print_headline: Trump Forced Top-Secret Clearance for Kushner

byline.original: By Maggie Haberman, Michael S. Schmidt, Adam Goldman and Annie Karni

docs.abstract: Justice Thomas has written more than 250 opinions scrutinizing precedents, calling for their reconsideration or suggesting that they be overruled.
docs.snippet: Justice Thomas has written more than 250 opinions scrutinizing precedents, calling for their reconsideration or suggesting that they be overruled.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Justice Clarence Thomas was busy in February. As usual, he asked no questions during Supreme Court arguments. But he made up for his silence with three opinions in eight days that took issue with some of the court’s most prominent precedents.

headline.main: Precedent, Meet Clarence Thomas. You May Not Get Along.
headline.print_headline: That’s a Settled Precedent? Thomas Disagrees

docs.abstract: The New Jersey Supreme Court had stopped payments to churches, saying the State Constitution barred them.
docs.snippet: The New Jersey Supreme Court had stopped payments to churches, saying the State Constitution barred them.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court announced Monday that it would not hear a case about whether a New Jersey county could allow churches to participate in grant programs for historic preservation even though the State Constitution forbids using tax money “for building or repairing any church.”

headline.main: Supreme Court Won’t Hear Case on Church Repairs Using Tax Money
headline.print_headline: Justices Will Not Hear Case On Funding Church Repairs
